reviewText: Tommy Lee Jones' 'The Three Burials of Melquiades Estrada' reinvents the Western by making it modern with a fresh rendering of old themes and plot.  The movie straddles the Texas-Mexican border with illegal immigrants filtering into a hot, sleepy Texas town.  Mike Norton (Barry Pepper) has just joined the border patrol and settled into a mobile home with his pretty young wife.  He is a selfish, distracted, and overly zealous new recruit who uses brutality to be successful on his new job.  Meanwhile, there are love interests that intersect lives.  Pete Perkins (Jones), a ranch foreman, is having an affair with the local diner's cook's wife, and Norton's wife is stepping out to have some fun with the ranch hand, Melquiades (Julio Cedillo).  Coincidentally, it is that same hand who shoots a fox to keep the predator off the sheep.  When Norton hears these shots on border patrol, he believes they are meant for him.  The trigger-happy Norton recklessly shoots and kills Melquiades.  When Perkins gets wind of this act, the grief-stricken rancher kidnaps Norton and makes him dig up his newly buried body.  He then makes him transport the two of them and the corpse on horse and donkeys across the rugged Mexican terrain until Norton can give his victim a decent burial near his home.The film is beautifully shot.  It takes a new approach to the Western revenge motif, and the plot creates a laudable adventure.  Wonderfully, we are pulled out of ourselves to consider humanity more than cattle.  The indifference of the Texas citizens to the plight of the fleeing Mexicans is contrasted by the focus on one of the border's victims, Melquiades--someone with a human face and dignity.  Someone who has passion and interest in beauty and humor.  Someone who wouldn't do anyone harm.  Notably, the movie is an absorbing work--not just a conscienceness-raising exercise.  Jones and company seldom preach--because they don't need to.  Being able to see life on both sides of the border is a plus.  Despite Norton's recklessness, the revenge is a bit overbearing, but it is realistic as well.  The lifestyles and people are documented well for border Mexico and the U.S.  Even though 'Melquiades' is a beautiful piece of art, there are a few too many coincidences--even if they do it in a way that is thoroughly forgiveable.  And forgiveness here is needed.

reviewText: Beautifully written and exquisitely acted and photographed, the enigmatic Three Burials of Melquiades Estrada is a fiercely provocative contemporary Western that is at once rough and poetic, laconic and passionate. It's about life and death, loyalty and betrayal and it brings to the forefront in a most compassionate and humanistic way the often-divisive politics of border control.Beginning in a somewhat prosaic fashion, the narrative jumps backwards and forwards in time and at first this technique may be a little disconcerting for some viewers. The easygoing laconic Melquiades Estrada (Julio Cesar Cedillo) - an illegal Mexican working in the United States for the kindly cowboy Pete Perkins (Tommy Lee Jones) - has been brutally shot.Suspicion immediately falls on Mike Norton (Barry Pepper), a tight, sexually frustrated US border patrolman. The local sheriff (Dwight Yoakam) doesn't care; to him Melquiades was just another annoying wetback, and his nonchalant attitude towards finding the killer angers Pete. When he was alive, Pete and Melquiades had formed a close friendship, defined by a gentle dignity that rises about race, culture and politics. At one stage - told in flashback - Mel even begs Pete to return him to his home to his wife and family in Mexico if ever he dies in the United States.Eventually, Pete decides to take the law into his own hands and pistol-whips Mike into accompanying him back to Mexico with the increasingly rotting and decaying corpse of Mel for company. Meanwhile, back at the border Mike's wife, Lou Ann (January Jones), young and blond and bored, just can't wait to get away from this dusty tin-pot backwater. And Pete's girlfriend Rachel (Melissa Leo), the married, whorey waitress at his favorite diner, laments the fact that she's middle-aged and can't summon up the courage to leave her husband.Throughout the first act, director Tommy Lee Jones lets the characters run into each other in surprising and unexpected ways. Much of the drama comes from the fact that the protagonists are all such dangerous opposites: the crusty old cowpoke Pete, is embittered and frustrated, determined to revenge his dear friend's death; Mike is bored and frightened, he's an inexperienced as a border guard who keep's Mel's murder to himself, hoping against hope that he won't be discovered; then there's the gentle Melquiades, who even in death, haunts those who meet him.Behind these three characters and cementing their mutual experiences, is the shared experience of a dying world, where life is but a hand-to-mouth itinerancy, and where the life they so love is forsaken for a shabby, cramped existence in run down apartments and squalid makeshift trailers. In this world, country songs and wayward wives, greasy spoon diners and seedy motels, and the constant politics of border life, drown the harsh physical beauty of the Texas landscape.The tone of the movie is tough and gritty, almost irreverent, and all the performances are edgy and raw, the characters constantly being battered, worn out by the world around them, lazy and cynical at the same time. Cinematographer Chris Menges magnificently captures the very real beauty of the Mexican desert and Tommy Lee Jones directs the whole proceedings with a languid and fluid style that lends itself well to this type of material.Three Burials of Melquiades Estrada is an introspective and meditative film. None of the characters really know what they want out of life, except of course, Pete with his single-minded determination to make Mike pay for his crime. And of course Mike must pay, even though he admits it was an accident. Redemption comes in the form of a terrible journey across the border into the heart of Mexico, where Mike must finally comes to terms with all of his faults and limitations.For his part, Pete demands a payback and a reckoning for Mike, he's determined to carry out his dead friend's wishes at whatever cost. Unfortunately, for both of them, this transformational journey, this epic trip into the core of the earth, doesn't really help either of them find any real serenity or peace of mind. Mike Leonard June 06.

reviewText: "The Three Burials of Melquiades Estrada" is rather strange movie as it seems at the first glance. Its slow-paced manner and non-chronological scene order confuse viewer at first, but then you begin to realize everything is at its place, everything is very correct and precise.Melquiades Estrada, an illegal Mexican immigrant in a small town in Texas and a friend of a local cowboy Pete (played by Tommy Lee Jones) is accidentally shot dead by a border patrol officer Mike (Barry Pepper). Once before Pete promised to Melquiades that if the latter dies first he'd take his body to Estrada's hometown of Jimenez in Mexico. Pete keeps his promise, trying to achieve two goals - accomplish last will of his friend and to punish the killer. But it won't be a punishment a la Dirty Harry. Pete is a wise man and he seeks mental and emotional vengeance. And it's only possible if a man repents at his own wish. Pete handcuffs Pepper's character and takes him along to this exhausting and killing journey across mountains and Mexican desert to Estrada's hometown. All these days they will be carrying Melquiades' decaying body in a sack.The film reminded me of "Dead Man" by Jim Jarmusch - it has these spiritual wandering, soul-seeking and exploring the worlds that lie beyond our everyday's routine. Sometimes it is possible to understand something only making this journey, pushing yourself to the limit when boundary between life and death fades, and you start seeing things around you as they are.This meaningful journey is important for all three of them. Melquiades finally gets a chance to find home and rest in peace. Pete drops the weight of a promise from his shoulders, manages to suppress his rage towards the man who killed his best friend, and in general thinks over his relationships with other people. And Mike gets a chance to be born again emotionally, to become some other person, I'd say really better person.This is a truly astonishing and very delicate drama about ordinary people who quit being ordinary due to certain extraordinary events. This movie is a reminder to all of us - to stop, to look at ourselves from the outside and to ponder what we are doing on this planet. Maybe this film will make someone a better person - I understand it sounds in grand style, but that was what I really felt after watching. It's very rare when we come across such serious and thoughtful pictures, that's for sure. If you are a thinking man - watch it, the film will give you a lot of food for thought.

reviewText: In a nutshell, Melquiades Estrada, an illegal immigrant from Mexico, is shot and buried in a shallow grave in West Texas by a border patrolman. Estrada's body is found and reburied in a pauper's grave in a local cemetery. After kidnapping the killer and forcing him to disinter the body, Estrada's best friend and employer, Pete (Tommy Lee Jones), takes the border patrol agent with him as he undertakes to return Estrada's body to his hometown in Mexico, to be buried as he had promised him. The film was inspired by the real-life killing in Texas. Telling you any more runs the risk of  "spoilers."This is Tommy Lee Jones' second time as a director, the first being for a made for TV, The Good Old Boys, in 1995. As with his directing debut, he acquits himself admirably, establishing him as a serious directorial talent. This movie won him Best Director at the Cannes Film Festival, as well as Best Screenplay for Guillermo Arriaga. Tommy Lee Jones was also nominated for, but did not win, the Palme d'Or, the highest award given at Cannes.This is a spectacular film, with splendid acting from just about every main actor and actress. It is highly recommended.NOTE: The version available here is of Taiwanese manufacture. The transfer is good but not great, as is the sound. It is English language with some Spanish (with subtitles). Amazon UK has a different Blu-Ray version.Regardless of which version (either of the Blu-Rays or regular DVD), this is a film you should have in your collection. It will bear repeated watching over the years.

reviewText: With a title like this, one might think this would be a rather depressing story. Burying someone three times seems ...well ...dark. And although The Three Burials of Melquiades Estrada has its dark tones, the film is anything but depressing. Directed and starring Tommy Lee Jones (LONESOME DOVE), the movie watcher is guided through a plot unlike any I've seen.Nonlinear storylines in film are not uncommon (ala MOMENTO) and this one takes us down that well-trodden path, too. But here we get to see the burial of Melquiades Estrada (Julio Cedillo, THE ALAMO) through multiple viewpoints. First we see it through Pete Perkins' (Tommy Lee). He's a rancher who befriends the luckless Mexican. Melquiades Estrada crossed the Mexico/Texas border illegally and is simply looking to make a better life for himself. He tells Pete that he wants to make things better for his wife and children in Mexico, too, but that if anything should happen to him, Pete has to promise to take him back to his little hometown in Mexico and bury him. Pete reluctantly agrees.Next we get to see Mike Norton (Barry Pepper, SAVING PRIVATE RYAN ), a newly employed US Border Patrol Agent and his wife Lou Ann (January Jones, LOVE ACTUALLY) move to a one-horse border town. Lou Ann is a shallow and immature young woman who only wants to go to "the mall" and sexually pleases her husband in as boring a fashion one could imagine. Barry's gung-ho attitude quickly gets him into trouble on the job. He hates these Mexicans who are continually trying to cross the border. Always on the lookout for "the enemy" Barry's thoughtless reaction to stray gunshots being fired end up causing Melquiades Estrada's death. Barry covers it up (the first burial) and tries to forget about it.The third set of eyes which we get to see the burials from are, surprisingly, Melquiades himself. After his death and first burial, his corpse is soon discovered and brought into town for identification. His name is incorrectly listed, a grave marker erected, and he's unceremoniously buried again (#2).When Pete discovers what happened to his friend, and who was responsible, he quickly takes matters into his own hands. Pete ain't happy that Mike Norton (Pepper) isn't being punished for what he did. Few know about it and those that do are within the brotherhood of law enforcement. Sooo ...Pete kidnaps Mike, forces him to dig up Melquiades' body, then makes him haul the decaying corpse back to Mexico.They cross the border and have great difficulty locating the dead man's hometown. No one in Mexico recognizes the name of it, including his wife. His wife? Doesn't she live in the town? Nope. In fact, the picture of his wife and kids that Melquiades showed Pete aren't really his. Why did he lie? Pete decides to find the town anyway and bury his friend there. His search seems nearly fruitless until he stumbles across a small half torn-down building in the middle of nowhere. He decides that this MUST be the place. But is it? Much is left to the viewer's interpretation here. Was Melquiades crazy or deluded? Or did Pete REALLY find the town?Regardless, Pete makes Mike bury Melquiades (the third time!) and then releases Mike. It's a poignant moment when Pete releases him because much has transpired since their ordeal began. Mike is now in Mexico amongst "the enemies" he perceived when he was on the other side of the border. But now, being in their midst, his radical tone softens. But it's a hard realization and the film pulls it off without becoming trite.Tommy Lee Jones is an able actor and director and this film proves it. Of course, Barry Pepper is no slouch either. Both pull in excellent performances and the scenes of the Rio Grande and border towns are perfectly portrayed.This is a must see.
summary: Tommy Lee's Best Since Lonesome Dove

reviewText: I'm not sure what the meaning is of this movie directed by and starring Tommy Lee Jones is. I certainly felt there must be one. Jones plays Pete Perkins, a rancher in west Texas. Estrada was a Mexican Jones hired. One day Estrada shoots at a coyote. A border patrolman, Mike Norton, thinks he was the target and fires back, killing Estrada. Norton hides the body. When Perkins finds out what happened he kidnaps Norton and makes Norton dig up the body. Estrada was Perkins' best friend. He used to talk to Perkins about his village in Mexico, a small place between two hills, with fresh water and green trees. Perkins is determined to take Estrada's body to the village. He'll take Norton, in chains, with him and Norton will rebury Estrada with dignity.For the rest of the movie we follow Perkins, Norton and Estrada's decomposing body on their journey through the harsh, hot Mexican land to find the village. Along the way they have strange meetings with people they encounter...an old, blind man living by himself who wants Perkins to shoot him, a woman who might be Estrada's wife, a group of illegal aliens and a rattlesnake, several Mexican cowboys who offer water and meat. All along this journey Perkins is taciturn, unforgiving of Norton and capable. He talks to his friend's increasingly decayed body, and tries to preserve it with anti-freeze and to comb its hair.  Norton shows himself to be immature, scared, and desperate. When Perkins eventually finds Estrada's home, Norton buries Estrada while Perkins watches. There is an act of humanity that closes the movie.Jones has directed his movie masterfully. It is thoughtful, well-paced and, with the decaying body, has a little queasy humor. The journey at times is nearly surreal. I'm still not sure what the message was, but the movie is so good I'm almost positive that not getting it is my fault, not Joneses.

reviewText: Tommy Lee Jones was the driving force behind the low budget western formatted tale about the virtues of friendship in the movie he produced, directed and starred in, "The Three Burials of Melquiades Estrada".Filmed near the panoramic Texas-Mexico border in Big Bend National Park, Jones plays Pete Perkins , a grizzled ranch foreman.  Perkins takes on newly arrived illegal Mexican cowhand, Melquiades Estrada, played by Julio Cedillo, as part of his crew.  The men soon form a solid friendship.Tragically Estrada is accidently shot dead by newly commissioned border patrol agent Mike Norton, played by underrated talent Barry Pepper, while on patrol in the remote desert.  Due to the "wetback" status of the victim, the crime is covered up by impotent town sheriff Belmont, played surprisingly well by C&W;'s Dwight Yoakam.  Jones learn of the actual circumstances of the crime and abducts Pepper, forcing him to disinter the hastily buried corpse of Estrada.The two men, Jones with Pepper as his manacled prisoner embark on a perilous journey across the border to bury Estrada in his beloved homestead according to his wishes.  The odyssey serves as penitence for the insensitive and often brutal Pepper and also solidifies the bonds of friendship felt by Jones towards his slain comrade.

reviewText: This movie really took me by surprise.  I expected it to be good, I certainly didn't expect it to move me the way it did.  Tommy Lee Jones is outstanding.  Barry Pepper portrays the conflicted Border Patrol agent.  Julio Cedillo plays the title character who we get to know through flashbacks.  The film shows both sides of a tragic situation and takes you through the transformation of Mike Norton as he makes his trek with Pete Perkins to take Melquiades home.  There are some interesting little subplots that do not detract from the main story.  No pat Hollywood ending here, you will be thinking about this film long after the credits have rolled.Kudos to Tommy Lee Jones, this is an outstanding film.  There are some overtones of Lonesome Dove here, but that's all good since THAT movie was incredible.It's a shame this movie didn't make a bigger showing in theaters.  I loved the way the characters were portrayed as human beings you can relate to, even if the language is different.  The beginning was a little confusing until it becomes clear that most of the story is told in flashbacks and different perspectives.  The killing scene is shown twice, once from the viewpoint of the killer, the other from the victim's perspective.This is a great film.  I hope more people take the time to watch it.  It is also timely given the current state of affairs in this country.  Regardless of your opinion of illegal immigration, this film puts a human face on one immigrate who has come to this country to find honest work.

reviewText: while we waste time on Brokeback Mountain, this is the movie we must all see. I only regret it has no Spanish audio track to share more easily with my buddies across the border to the south. But this lack is not uncommon in DVD's, for reasons unclear. Why French but not Spanish, a huge market, especially for this film, which nevertheless includes Spanish dialogue, including Mr. Lee's?The intricate mixing of POV's and memory resembles Rashomon; taking a stance in resistance against terrorist superior force resembles Seven Samurai, (not its Sturges anti-Mexican brokeback remake Magnificent Seven) but mostly this is Tommy Lee Jones riding around his borderland ranch in a thoughtful tale of local friends and the pain they share in the face of unreasoning US militarization of their ancient lands.Study this film. Dare to grow understanding and compassion, something so discouraged nowadays.This movie rewards repeated and careful viewing, like an old novel. Upon careful viewing of this film, you find an epic essence (as Odysseus or Dante) wrapped in a tale of sin, a coming to grief, and repentance, seeking atonement, and ultimate redemption in new life. Tommy Lee serves as Virgil in Dante's trilogy Inferno to Paradiso, guiding the sinful Norton through stages of undenying recognition of sin and selfishness, through cleansing (including a baptismal dip in the River Jordon, or passing the River Styx into the underworld), unto rebirth and epiphany. It is not sadism but the purifying passing through the rings of hell and purgatory to a beaitfic vision of redemption which drives Tommy Lee in carrying the vicious Border Patrol agent Norton "home" to peace and self-forgiveness for all of his selfish cruelty to others, to become able once more to reach out anew in love and concern and compassion for others.This film does not portray law enforcement and other official imperial oppressors as cruel, nor does it show all Mexicans as angelic in a prejudicial manner. Rather it reveals the essential injustice in itself which the border patrol enacts. Any armed official is a potential oppressor and a killer very tempted and even encouraged to abuse his power. But notice nevertheless that every other official cautions the main rookie hot dog border patroller Norton not to be so aggressive, violent and abusive. You cannot say that the officials are painted with a broad brush, as all the other, wiser, more experienced officials try to restrain this hot dog among them who makes their jobs tougher and poor people's lives miserable, until the effects of his own violent callous aggression result both in death of an innocent and the loss of his lovely wife.He abuses his wife in a loveless sexual manner. She is just too darn beautiful and nice and easygoing to treat so badly. And while on duty and beating off to a dirty magazine in the bushes, he hears rifle fire. He assumes in his solipsistic selfishness someone is shooting at him, but a local farmer is shooting the coyote who kill his sheep and goats. Norton hunts down the campesino who is now disarmed, returns fire, and kills him. Like Dick Cheney aiming at a bush his beaters drive baby quail into, he does not confirm his target.The inevitable results of this fatal action, guided by the great Tommy Lee, bring Norton back from the spiritually dead. This movie is really a morality play as profound as Orpheus Rising. In fact, like James Joyce's short stories ending with an epiphanl line revealing the meaning of it all, the final line illuminates the entire process. Norton, the selfish (look how he makes "love" AT his wife) and violent aggressor, calls to the departing Tommy Lee, who leaves him dispossessed as any alien, and upon alien soil, with nothing, he calls out to the leaving Tommy Lee, ignoring his own predicament, as poor as Saint Francis: "You gonna be all right?"I do not reveal plot secrets in saying this, but I tell the purpose of this epic nearly biblical tale of redemption, the dawning of compassion and concern for the Other. The only interesting part of the rather sparse and unfocussed commentary with January and Dwight riding along is how this epiphanal final line was born and developed and aimed for. By the way, try to recognize the great and lonesome Dwight Yokum in this film. I see now why he hides under a huge hat and long duster coat.This really is the best damn movie Western or otherwise made this entire miserable empty millenium, and far too good for Hollywood. Best western ever made, including that one you are thinking of. In fact it is a European production done by Tommy Lee Jones mostly on his own border ranch.

reviewText: n this his debut as a director, Tommy Lee Jones plays Pete Perkins, a grizzled cattle rancher on the Texas-Mexico border. Pete befriends and bonds with an illegal immigrant named Melquiades Estrada whom he hired as a ranch hand. He also promised to bury Melquiades back in his hometown if he happened to die north of the border. In a freak accident, a rookie border patrol agent named Mike Norton murders Melquiades, who had fired in his direction at a coyote. Pete knows that the redneck immigration authorities will do nothing, so in an act of vigilante justice he exhumes Melquiades, forces Norton to carry his body across the most lonesome, isolated, hostile territory you can imagine, and eventually gives him a proper burial. In the end, Norton asks forgiveness for killing Melquiades (disproving his wife Lou Anne's judgment that he's "a sonofabitch beyond redemption"), who otherwise remind us of all the many obscure, insignificant people whose fates are forgotten by the world--but not by someone as loyal as Tommy Lee Jones. reviewText: In the beginning this reminded me of The Border (1982) starring Jack Nicholson and Harvey Keitel.  A new border guard and his wife arrive in a south Texas town and live in a trailer.  She's bored stiff while her husband learns the new job and the border patrol culture.  However instead of all the corruption that Jack Nicholson found, here we find that it is the new border guard who is morally corrupt.  What is surprising is how easily Three Burials gradually turns into a 21st century Western with the classic revenge theme played out in a most dramatic way.Tommy Lee Jones stars as Pete Perkins, a weathered cowboy somewhat past his prime who befriends a Mexican--the Melquiades Estrada (Julio Cedilla) of the title--who has come across the border.  One day when the new border guard Mike Norton is out in the hills looking for wetbacks (actually horny Mike has a Hustler magazine in his hands and his pants half down, and he's about to do something else) he hears a rifle shot nearby.  He pulls his pants up, runs to his vehicle, grabs his rifle and then just shoots the first target he sees.  It's Melquiades Estrada.  And he is now dead. reviewText: The spirit of Sam Peckinpah lives on (sans slo-mo) in "The Three Burials of Melquiades Estrada". Director Tommy Lee Jones casts himself as a contemporary Texas cowboy named Pete who befriends a Mexican "vaquero" (the namesake of the movie's title). Estrada is an illegal looking for steady work and a brighter future here in the land o'plenty. Jones utilizes flashbacks to illustrate the growing kinship between the two compadres, who bond in the usual "cowboy way"-drinkin' and whorin',sleeping under the stars, and reaching a general consensus that A Cowboy's Life Is The Life For Me (as a great man once sang.) In the key vignette, Estrada confides that, if "something" should ever happen to him, he wishes to be buried in his home town. In half-drunken sentiment, Pete vows to see it through if the unthinkable happens. Guess what happens next?When Estrada is mysteriously killed, Pete becomes incensed by the indifference of the local authorities, who seem reluctant to investigate. When he learns through the grapevine that his friend was the victim of negligent homicide, thanks to a boneheaded border patrol officer (Barry Pepper), he goes ballistic. He abducts the officer, forces him to dig up the hastily buried Estrada, and informs him that the three amigos are taking a little horseback trip to Mexico (and it ain't gonna be anything like "Weekend at Bernie's").Much unpleasantness ensues as the story evolves into a "man on a mission to fulfill an oath" tale...on the surface. Despite the simplistic setup, astute viewers will begin to realize that there is a deeper, mythic subtext; this is one of those films that can really sneak up on you. Although my initial reaction was more visceral than philosophical (I didn't find any of the characters particularly likeable, it started to feel overlong, and I was repulsed by some of the more graphic scenes) I eventually realized that I had just been taken on an Orphic journey, and it suddenly all made sense. The film gives you hope that, despite the rampant cynicism that abounds in this world, there is something to be  said for holding true to a personal code that covets friendship, loyalty and a deep sense of honor.

reviewText: There is little doubt that Tommy Lee Jones has potential as an absurdist filmmaker, but this snail's-paced, oddly discomforting 2005 film is neither a mythic tale nor a prodigious directorial debut for the veteran actor. The pokey momentum and arid West Texas locations remind me a bit of Bruce Beresford's 1983 "Tender Mercies", but Guillermo Arriaga's screenplay lifts the intriguing plot device of Sam Peckinpah's 1974 "Bring Me the Head of Alfredo Garcia" to move the story forward. Unfortunately, the resulting film does not come close to either classic because of its unsavory characters, implausible and often irrelevant story turns and worst of all, the deadening pace of the whole venture.It focuses on local rancher Pete Perkins, who finds out through the local sleep-around waitress that his friend and ranch hand, Melquiades Estrada, an Illegal Mexican immigrant, has been shot dead by a new border patrolman named Mike Norton. The first half of the overlong film shifts back and forth in time and bounces among characters that may or may not matter at the end, while the second half is a desultory trek where Perkins is intent on bringing Estrada's decaying body back across the border to his hometown. This is where the absurdist aspect comes to fruition as Perkins goes to extreme measures to preserve the body and the intent of the mission. I was hopeful the more straightforward narrative that takes hold on the journey would lead to a greater emotional resonance, but what it really does is elongate the story unnecessarily.Jones is fine as Perkins, though his character is mostly a cipher as we are never clear why Estrada is that meaningful a friend to him. Barry Pepper has an unenviable task playing the surly Norton, and he bears the brunt of the plot's absurdities in the second half. Dwight Yoakam portrays the local sheriff on one consistently sour note, though there are decent sideline contributions by Julio Cedillo as Estrada and Melissa Leo as the waitress. Levon Helm shows up in a cameo as an old, blind farmer, but I couldn't help but be reminded of Gene Hackman's bit as the blind monk in "Young Frankenstein". Give credit to Chris Menges for his appropriately sun-scorched cinematography of the desolate terrain. The DVD is sparse on extras - a full-screen or widescreen viewing option and a relatively terse commentary track by Jones, Yoakam and actress January Jones, who has a red-herring role as Norton's bored wife Lou Ann. In a relatively head-scratching move, the Cannes Film Festival jury bestowed awards for Jones' acting and Arriaga's screenplay last year.
summary: Little Payoff for a Plodding Tex-Mex Combo of Black Comedy and Melodrama Full of Red Herrings

reviewText: THE THREE BURIALS OF MELQUIADES ESTRADA (a/k/a LOS TRES ENTIERROS DE MELQUIADES ESTRADA, Dir. Tommy Lee Jones, 2006, erroneously listed as 2005, 122 minutes, in English and subtitled Spanish, based on a true story).This was some film, beautifully acted and quite a stunning work of poetry. Being so close to it in time, and having only just seen it, I can't tell whether it's a classic or a weird cinematic phenomenon. As Tommy Lee Jones' directorial debut, it must be given its due weight ~ only I really am not certain what that weight should be. It's a true story, but it might not have been received warmly: I barely recall hearing of it years back, and I can't say Jones packed the houses or grabbed traction as a director with this film.Ranch hand Pete (Tommy Lee Jones) becomes infuriated when his best friend Melquiades (Julio César Cedillo) is shot and killed by a racist border patrol officer (Barry Pepper). The moment Pete is able to identify the officer, he kidnaps him, forces him to dig up Melquiades and sets off to rebury him in nearby Mexico. So far so good, because Pepper plays a horrendous individual and this entire film is a loud and clear statement about illegal Mexican immigration.In short, Jones wants us to see that Mexicans are human beings and are in America for survival. Jones also wants the viewer to somehow grasp the fact that Mexicans are exactly like Americans. It is clear from this film that Jones is trying to show us that some people have forgotten that fact. What Jones is trying to re-teach this country is the thing that made it possible for my parents to come here (legally in their case) from Mexico.I will cease my description there and make some random comments about this film. It stunned me and I loved it enough to keep watching it, in spite of some rather horrid slices of super-low-class life in southern Texas and other monstrosities. It seemed to me that Jones, while unflinching in the face of these things, at least showed them exactly as they might happen in real life (perhaps he is showing how they actually happened: this is a true story). No cinematic silliness for Jones, though he demonstrates an apt sense of humor with some funny moments.While Jones opted for a confusing beginning to his film, zapping back and forth in time, at least he did so with good, tight stitches. It is never a storytelling contrivance I enjoy, but Jones did his best with it. Like everyone else, a director is forced to take the risky approach of allowing twelve inches for a one-inch job. After that, there are a few oddities in the story that make no sense and are never explained ~ perhaps that is the mark of a newcomer director, no matter how gifted.The film was shot at Jones' ranch near Odessa, Texas, and the soundtrack is absolutely pitch-perfect, often consisting of Mexican and Country Western radio music along with the natural sounds occurring in the film. No superimposed swelling orchestras for Jones. It was of interest to me that Dwight Yoakam's music was prominently featured ~ as was Yoakam himself, who plays the hilariously weak-willed sheriff.It may also be of interest that the screenplay was originally written in Spanish, but was translated into English by Jones who is a fluent speaker ~ as this film will attest. (He was first heard speaking Mexican Spanish fluently inMen In Black.)BOTTOM LINE: This is a work I can respect, admire and praise highly. It is not for the faint of heart and I was frankly revolted by certain scenes. This is a film I will therefore never own, and probably won't see again ~ but I say a true film buff is a fool for missing a chance to see it once.

reviewText: Tommy Lee Jones makes an impressive debut as a director with this superlative atmospheric film based on the writing of Guillermo Arriaga who has proved his mettle with such screenplays as  '21 Grams' and 'Amores Perros'.  This is one of those rare 'westerns' where the plot is woven so tightly into the scenery that it takes a legion of excellent actors to unravel it.  And Jones has found those actors and has directed them in a mesmerizing story about friendship and the promises extracted from it.Pete Perkins (Tommy Lee Jones) is a dusty old man with friends wherever he sets his hat - be that in a cafe where knows the married waitress Rachel (a brilliant Melissa Leo) as a bed partner, or on his cowboy runs where his best friend is a Mexican man Melquiades Estrada (Julio Cedillo), a friendship bonded by promises and gifts and commitment.  When Melquiades is killed, Pete is grief stricken and cannot tolerate the attitude of the Border Patrol rednecks who just want to bury the Mexican without investigating the killing.  A new agent Mike Norton (Barry Pepper) and his wife Lou Ann (January Jones) have recently arrived from Cincinnati: Lou Ann is bored and spends her time in Rachel's cafe and cavorts with Rachel, Pete and Melquiades and Mike takes out his aggressions on his job.  When all evidence points to Mike Norton as the killer of Melquiades, Pete captures him, makes him confess to the killing, dig up Melquiades body so that Pete can return it as promised to Jimenez, Mexico.  The remainder of the film is a 'road trip' as Pete makes Mike transport Melquiades' rotting body into Mexico.  They encounter a blind man (Levon Helm) who befriends them and asks them as a return favor to shoot him: he is blind, alone, and his once visiting son is dying of cancer.  Pete refuses and heads on.  The travails of the trip are numerous but in the course of the story important lessons are learned by all of the characters.The movement of the film is a bit confusing at times as it is not told in a linear fashion: events revolving around Melquiades' death are slowly unwound in a way that makes the story a mystery of sorts.  The cinematography is stunning (Chris Menges) and the musical score by Marco Beltrami is hauntingly perfect.  Barry Pepper and Tommy Lee Jones turn in bravura performances, as does the rest of the cast in their more minor roles.  The after burn of the film is scorching and tender at the same time and the credit for that goes to Jones as director.  It is a brilliant achievement.  Highly Recommended.  Grady Harp, June 06
summary: One of the Great Films of 2005

reviewText: This is a great film replete with suggestive symbols of grace, redemption, magical thinking, loss and the boundaries that are personal, cultural, and spiritual, not merely geographic.  Ironically, when a dreamless, aimless Barry Pepper, who seems already past his prime at 30 becomes a member of the border patrol, he shoots an anonymous Mexican (Jones's blood brother so to speak)--and not even having the sympathy to try to help him--in fact, not having the humanity to even touch him as he lies bleeding to death--is more concerned about his job than another human being.  In this case the Mexican to him is merely a type, not really a person.  On the other hand Tommy Lee Jones, who sees the person behind the persona, is more concerned about the soul than the outward trappings of language or labels.  When he discovers his friend dies at the hands of Pepper, Jomes sits in his friend's modest shack just to feel his presence--to commune with his dead friend, as a means of coming to terms with his grief.  Faced with the indifferent locals who would rather save their butts than save their souls, Jones takes it on himself to become the humanizing agent in a mercenary world.  Forcing the border guard at gunpoint to accompany his friend to his final burial place, he traverses a bleak land that could be the Eliot's wasteland or the underworld.  When he brings his friend home, he finds to his surprise, this beloved Mexican town is not what it is described to be.  But as he understands that sometimes the imagination fulfills a purpose that life cannot, dignifies the death of his friend and redeems the humanity of the border guard.  This film shows how human relations matter; how the electronic media are mere illusion producing devices; and even an old cowboy's body can find the fountain of youth by sticking to basic principles of human decency and understanding, and even the most direloneliness can be overcome even miles from home.

reviewText: Tommy Lee Jones both directs and stars in this absurdist tale about murder and redemption on the rugged Mexican / American border.  After ranch hand / illegal immigrant Melquiades Estrada (Julio Cedillo) is discovered dead, his bilingual friend Pete Perkins (Tommy Lee Jones) sets out to find his killer. When Pete discovers that a border patrolman, loose-canon Mike Norton (Barry Pepper), is responsible for Melquiades' death, Pete kidnaps Mike and unearths the corpse of Melquiades.  After strapping Melquiades' rotting body to a donkey, Pete and Mike cross the border to Mexico in search of Mequiades' final resting place, the mysterious village Jimenez.The first half of the film is slightly surreal and filmed with a drowsy, listless beauty, cutting between scenes of border patrols at work in the wide open Texas countryside, Pete's investigation in to the death of Melquiades, and the lives of some of the townsfolk  -- Sheriff Belmont  (Dwight Yoakam), Lou Ann Norton (January Jones), and Rachel (Melissa Leo) -- as they cope with the dullness of their border town lives.  Screenwriter Guillermo Arriaga weaves together these disparate scenes via a series of flashbacks, which adds to a feeling of gentle confusion.The mood and form of the film changes after the first hour and the film becomes an extended morality tale in which an emotionally dead, borderline sadistic, border patrolman learns that Mexicans are people too -- thanks to the patience of his teacher/torturer Pete. In my opinion the second half of the film was weaker than the first half. The scenes dragged a bit.  Some of the Mexican / American role reversals - for example, a scene in which Mike escapes from Pete and tries to run for his freedom and into Mexico - felt a bit manipulative.  Some may wonder, why are all the white men villains except for Pete?  And did we really need to see so much corpse grooming?But these debatable flaws aside, I think this film is worth seeing because it deals with a topic that most people are thinking about these days: immigration and the Mexican / American border.  For someone like me, who has never been to southern Texas, the film gave me the slightest sense of what border county looks and feels like  -- something that I can't get from a 30 second video on the evening news. ***1/2

reviewText: Let's face it, 2006-2007 have been two of the worse years in movie-making history. It seems like the well-thought-out drama has become extinct and given way to the slash-up-a-tourist or demon genres. Even the indy circuit seems pressed to deliver agenda-laden films instead of stories that speak to us. Upon viewing The Three Burials of Melquiades Estrada, however, I now know there is still hope.It is clear that Jones poured his heart and soul into directing this film and for someone who co-starred in perhaps the western genres greatest story ever - Lonesome Dove - Jones was just the man to direct and star in this movie.The story (written mastefully by Guillermo Arriaga) settles in on a friendship between two cowboys. One is a Texan (Jones) and the other is a gentle Mexican named Melquiades (Julio Cedillo). We see through flashbacks that the two men develop a quick and dynamic bond. This bond is so strong that it survives the death of Melquiades, who is killed by a trigger-happy and thoughtless border guard named Mike Norton (Barry Pepper). Pete Perkins (played by Jones) is determined to bury his friend in a town Melquiades called home while living in Mexico and makes sure that Norton comes along for the journey, willingly or otherwise.Seldom have I witnessed a message as pure as the one found in this film, and that message revolves around the boundlessness of true friendship. Friendship does not come lightly to Pete Perkins as he sets out to honor the memory of his friend while at the same time attempting to teach Norton that real redemption comes at a high cost.As for the last 10 minutes of the film, words cannot suffice. You will simply have to watch it and sit in awe of the power that comes from understanding wholly and completely the dreams of another and making them your own. It is here, at the end of the journey, where we see the world as Perkins sees it, and as Melquiades first saw it.
summary: Instills hope that movies can still be powerful.

The two had become compadres, drinking and womanizing together - real Guy Stuff. In a moment of sentimentality, Perkins promised to convey Estrada's body back home to an isolated, tiny hamlet in northern Mexico should the latter ever die on the U.S. side of the border. Melquiades shows Perkins a picture of his wife and writes out rough directions to the place, just in case.The only evidence at the scene of the shooting is a spent rifle cartridge, which, to Pete's experienced eyes, could only belong to the U.S. Border Patrol. He's enraged when that agency refuses to investigate further into the death of his friend. Later, through a third party, Perkins learns the identity of the shooter, border patrolman Mike Norton (Barry Pepper), who regards illegal border crossers as something less than human. Pete saddles up and sets about fulfilling his promise to Melquiades, while taking the opportunity to teach Mike a well-deserved lesson. By this time in the screen action, however, the viewer has also seen a flashback to the circumstances surrounding Estrada's death, which perhaps leaves the audience with a trace of pity for the otherwise unlikable Norton.While a tangential (un)intended effect of TBoME is to engender sympathy for the thousands of impoverished illegals crossing America's southern border every year, the main message is one of God's righteous retribution. And who better to be its deliverer than the craggy, weather-beaten, and tough Jones? (For all I know, God's visage is that of Tommy Lee.) In LONESOME DOVE, Cap'n Call declares that he won't tolerate rude behavior in a man after having given an appropriate thumping to a loutish Army scout. Here, Perkins has that same aversion, and proceeds to demonstrate to a level that perhaps has the viewer wondering if he's a bit too zealous in making his point. However, Divine Justice can be hard and gritty, especially in south Texas.I saw TBoME at a private studio screening in November of '05. Coming out, I thought it, like THE LIBERTINE starring Johnny Depp, would not be amenable to a holiday season release. It's definitely not a picture for the frivolous only out for a dinner & movie feel-good experience. This is a tough and uncompromising morality play about private responsibility, personal accountability, friendship, loyalty, and redress of a wrong. As such, it may be limited to the movie art houses, and is worth seeking out if it's not at your local megaplex in company with the usual cinematic fluff.TBoME isn't Best Picture material, but I'm giving five stars because it makes its point forcefully and faultlessly, and Tommy Lee Jones is in top form.

reviewText: MOVIE: It seems like every actor is trying their hand at directing nowadays. Kevin Costner, Mel Gibson, George Clooney, Denzel Washington, and John Malkovich are examples of actors who have tried their handywork behind the camera. Ron Howard and Clint Eastwood are two that have basically made the switch and now exclusively work behind the camera. Tommy Lee Jones' directorial debut is nothing short of amazing cinema. The western is making a comeback (too bad everyone forgot about Leone) and some of Hollywood's best is tackling the genre. This film is about a rancher named Pete (Tommy Lee Jones) and his good friend Melquiades, who is an illegal alien working for him. They bond together as they work on the ranch, sharing past experiences and a longing for something more in their lives. On the other side of the equation we have Mike Norton (Barry Pepper) who has moved to Texas with his wife so he can work with Border Patrol. The film opens when two border patrolmen discover the body of Melquiades half buried under a bush, and the first act is told out of sequence. We jump forward in time and back to reveal the situation. Norton is shown as this man with no tolerance and no regard for anyone. In one scene while his wife is in the kitchen making dinner he comes in and just has sex with her as she lays over the counter, during the whole thing she just watches tv. So you can see the relationship they have together. Later in the film she resorts to prostitution to try and find a mean of entertaining herself, and she ends up spending a somewhat intimate moment with Melquiades, but Norton never knows it so it has nothing to do with what happens next. One day when Melquiades is herding some of the goats out to graze he sees a coyote and fires at it. Norton, off in the distance at his stakeout mistakes this for gunfire aimed at him and he fires back and kills him without thinking twice. Then we see the second burial of Melquiades. The film is seprated into 4 parts: the first burial of Melquiades Estrada, the second burial of Melquiades Estrada, the journey, and the third burial of Melquiades Estrada. Before the journey ensues we have a scene where Pete bursts in on Norton in his home and beats him up, cuffs him, and instructs him to dig up Melquiades. We then flashback to a conversation that Pete had with Melquiades and how Melquiades made Pete promise that if he ever dies here in Texas that Pete would take his body back to his homtown in Jimenez. Now the journey ensues as Pete forces Norton with him to take Melquiades back to Jimenez. The film is very well done, and the characters are fleshed out before the second act of the film so the audience is very involved. We have Pete, who is doing this for closure for his friend, but the audience never really fully understands Pete's reasoning for being so hostile. Norton takes quite a beating throughout the film, but it all serves for his redemption and to show a change of character. There is also an underlaying humor to the film, but it's a dark humor. There are intense scenes and will hold your attention and basically make you think "what the hell?!?", and the film's conclusion leaves a lot for interpretation. The characters really don't come full circle in their journey, basically the starting point and the end point are nowhere near to each other on the map. It's an amazing film that will captivate you and really shake you. Tommy Lee Jones does a superb job at maintaing a constant vision, I guess he felt so at home behind the camera since the movie was filmed on his ranch in Texas.ACTING: Tommy Lee Jones got a Best Actor award at Sundance, and when you see the movie you'll know why. He handles the character superbly, revealing some but not all about who Pete really is. Barry Pepper gives a full throttle performance showing different ranges of emotion from being extremely angry, being stubborn, being scared, frustrated, and resentful. The two of them share the most screen time in the movie, but they really never interact. Then, when you think about it the movie wouldn't work without one of them. The acting was fine work, and Tommy Lee Jones should be proud with what he has done in front of and behind the camera.BOTTOM LINE: Shot on the open landscapes of mountain ranges, deserts, and prairies of Texas and Mexico; The Three Burials Of Melquiades Estrada is a haunting film about personal journies and redemption. Fine performances with Jones' superb direction along with a subtle yet powerful score make this movie a gem worth looking for. It's a shame that this never got a wide release, I mean, it was only playing in 1 theater in my entire state. Luckily the theater was 5 minutes from my house. It'll be hard to find, but make sure you look for it on DVD.
summary: Well Worth Your While To Try & Find A Theater Playing This Gem

reviewText: The Western films of Classic Hollywood told us that the world was ostensibly a landscape of loneliness and alienation, where the only solace offered to a man was the unquestioning reliability and friendship of his gun, his horse, and himself. The more political New Criticism of later years told us that these films were ultimately cold and negative and that their true value lay only through a deconstruction of the racism, sexism and various other -isms that lay behind their gritty surfaces. "The Three Burials of Melquiades Estrada" tells us that perhaps those early Westerns were more accurate and true to life then we care to admit."Three Burials..." is a modern Western in the truest sense. Its setting is contemporary, as the film takes place in the present day and in the middle of the very real political atmosphere of border tensions and xenophobia. Its release during the reopened immigration issues of the United States speaks of its timeliness. The film is still a Western of a traditional variety, however, as it exists in a time and place that will be forever reminiscent of those films of old, where men still refered to themselves as cowboys, where everyone knew everyone and all their business, and where modern, urban America was still a mysterious, exciting, and foreign land. The film exhibits neither pastiche nor nostalgia in its echo of the classic Western, but instead recontextualizes and reexamines the sentiments and ideals that made audiences at first love, and then reject this important American genre.The story is simple. A rancher's best friend and coworker has been found dead. The man is Mexican and an illegal immigrant, so the police choose to do nothing. The rancher decides to take matters into his own hands as he seeks retribution while fulfilling his promise to return his friend's body to his Mexican home and family. What seems at first to be the classic western tale of murder and revenge, however, becomes enriched by the characters and locales which surround and tone the story. By way of these characters and stories, the film ultimately becomes one of companionship, one that examines the promise of the normative American narrative and the alienation and emptiness it breeds, and one that celebrates the friendship and redemption that crosses all borders, classes, and standards.One of the true virtues of the film is its pacing, which patiently reveals these characters and insights in a deliberate and accurate manner. The film may be slow to some, but for those willing to soak in the film at the pace it asks, they will be rewarded. Take the scene with Levon Helm as a blind man, living alone in the desert. The scene has bare relevance to the plot, and yet adds such depth and brevity to the film that it becomes of the most memorable. This is a film full of scenes of this nature, deep in purpose and colour, enriching the film as a whole. "The Three Burials of Melquiades Estrada" is a great film and well worth the contemplation and consideration it asks.

reviewText: Clearly influenced by Sam Peckinpah's "Bring Me the Head of Alfred Garcia" and filmmaking revolution resulting from Quentin Tarantino's "Pulp Fiction", "The Three Burials of Melquiades Estrada" is a masterful dramedy built around an inadvertant killing, friendship, revenge and loyalty.Tommy Lee Jones plays the lead role and directed the film, which takes place in a Texas border town where he has a friendship with the title character. Barry Pepper (Roger Maris from "61*") plays a dimwitted and ruthless border guard who accidentally kills Jones' friend.What results is an odyssey to return the dead friend to the place in Mexico he wants to be buried, a trip through badlands and snake bites with border guards chasing the pair throug the bleak Mexican landscape no film viewer has likely ever seen on celluloid. The finale is a cathartic end to the journey that creates some satisfaction amidst the rancor and chaos of the previous 100 minutes.What makes this film unique and memorable is Jones' adept direction to represent his personal quest for meaning after his friend's unlikely demise. Underlining the story's drama is the relationship of both men to the women in their lives and how those relationships are altered by the odyssey.Played out in loosely catalogued flashback and real time scenes, the script mimics the technique that made "Pulp Fiction" famous. Chris Menges' cinematography adds a dimension to the story that cannot be denied. Using the brilliant Texas and Mexico sun, every scene is perfectly lit in lengthy vistas of landscapes no one would choose."Three Burials" uses humor, irony, unpredictability and morality to tell a story that is unusual, incredible and simultaneously realistic. As an actor, Jones is understated yet resolute. As a director, his vision is of friendship that is unyielding and absolute, regardless of circumstance. This is a film that achieves much at every level, is exceptionally memorable, bears multiple viewings, and is one of the best movies of its type.
summary: An outstanding variant on "Bring Me the Head of Alfredo Garcia" and "Pulp Fiction"

reviewText: I suspected that "The Three Burials of Melquiades Estrada" had to be a pretty good story to not only get Tommy Lee Jones to work behind the camera as a director for the first time, but also to get him to once again play a cowboy taking the corpse of his friend home.  What this 2006 film has in common with "Lonesome Dove" is not the transportation of a dead friend to his rightful final resting place, but rather the way the act defines both the man and the friendship.  The important difference is that this time the character Jones plays takes another living soul along on the journey south.Jones plays Pete Perkins, who runs a small cattle ranch and has hired Melquiades Estrada (Julio Cedillo), an illegal immigrant from Mexico, to work with him.  When Melquiades is killed and the local sheriff (Dwight Yoakam) refuses to do anything about it, Pete takes care of matters himself.  He finds out that a young Border Patrol agent, Mike Norton (Barry Pepper), killed Melquiades, Pete captures him.  Norton had buried Melquiades to hide the crime and then the body was buried a second time.  Now Pete makes Norton did up the body of the man he killed, and then they head off on horses to Mexico so that Pete's friend can be returned to his family and buried in the town of Jimenez south of the Border.Essentially, then, you have three burials and a trip as the four key sections of the film.  "The Three Burials of Melquiades Estrada" is not a suspense film, where we wonder if Pete is going to be able to carry off his plans.  There are obstacles, but his success is never in doubt.  Pete is very much from the worldly school where a man does what a man has to do, and despite what the situation might force him to do we never forget that the corpse is the body of his friend.  Pursuing Pete and his captive is problematic since what Norton has done would become public knowledge, and this film is decidedly set in a fairly private world.  The punishment Pete has selected is not simply punitive, it is instructive and whether the credit belongs to the director or to writer Guillermo Arriaga ("Amores perros") it must be said this movie ends at the perfect moment on the perfect line.There are other characters, most notably January Jones as Lou Ann Norton, Melissa Leo as Rachel, and Levon Helm as the Old Man with the Radio, but they are relatively insignificant given what is happening with Jones and Pepper.  Flashbacks are used to show both Pete's friendship with Melquiades and to let us know exactly how he ended up getting killed.  Neither Pete nor Norton are privy to the other halves of the story, but then their purpose is primarily to allow us to know how each man came to be in this peculiar situation.  This is not a story about revenge, it is a character study and an object lesson.  What makes it powerful is the elegance of its simplicity, but the subject matter and the deterioration of the title character's body will not appeal to everyone's sensibilities.
summary: It is the journey to the final burial that matters in this object lesson

reviewText: I was pleasantly surprised by the quality of this fine 2005 Cannes Film Festival winner.  I've always known that Tommy Lee Jones was a fine actor.  However, he also directed this film with just the perfect amount of substance and understatement.  The theme, a journey of redemption, is played out as a modern fable.  And it seems as real as today's news stories about illegal immigrants.The setting is Texas.  The story is familiar.  A Mexican illegal immigrant is found dead in a shallow grave somewhere on the Texas side of the boarder.  The sheriff doesn't care.  He just wants to bury him and get it over with.  But Tommy Lee Jones, cast as a ranch foreman, identifies the body as Melquiades Estrada, a worker who he had befriended.  And so he does some investigation and discovers that Melquiades was killed by a young border patrol officer played by Barry Pepper.  Formerly, Tommy Lee Jones had promised his friend Melquiades that if he died on the American side of the border, he would make sure his body was brought back to his home town in Mexico.  And so, with a quiet determination, Tommy Lee Jones makes plans to do just that.In the meantime we meet the other characters who people this fascinating film. It all forms a mosaic. We meet the unhappy wife of the border patrol agent.  We meet a married waitress who works in the diner who just wants some fun.  And we soon learn that even though we dislike the border patrol cop immensely, we find out that Melquides' death was just a tragic accident.However, that is just the beginning of the story.  What follows is the journey that Tommy Lee Jones forces the border patrol cop to take to Mexico with the rotting corpse of Melquiades.  After all, Tommy Lee Jones has made a promise.  And along the way, the border patrol cop learns a valuable lesson.  The fact that nothing is quite what it seems makes this an even more interesting film, with twists and turns along the way.  And by the end, there are a few threads of the plot that are purposely left unanswered.This is a fine film in every sense of the word.  The acting is exquisite.  And the screenplay intricate enough to give the audience more information than the characters ever really have.  Yes.  It can be depressing.  And we learn more than we ever wanted to about a decomposing corpse.  But the film is real and engrossing on so many levels that I give this film one of my highest recommendations.  Not for the squeamish of course.  But well worth it for the rest of us.
summary: Nothing is quite what it seems in this modern story of redemption.  A truly great film!

reviewText: First time full-feature director Tommy Lee Jones hits his first film out of the park, combining the traditions of Sam Peckinpah with a sprinkle of everything else.  Not since Clint Eastwood's 1992 Oscar-winner Unforgiven has a western been so violent, gruesome, and able to dig deep into the depths of the human pathos.  Originally released in 2005 at the Cannes film festival, I am going to consider this for my best of 2006 list, mainly because it wasn't available to the public until earlier this year.  Jones not only directs, but gives one of his best performances since his 1993 Oscar-winning performance in The Fugitive.  Jones plays Pete Perkins, an aging ranch hand in West Texas, who quickly befriends a Mexican illegal immigrant who works at the ranch, named, accordingly, Melquiades Estrada (Julio Cedillo).  Melquiades is gunned down by mistake by Mike Norton, a trigger-happy border patrolman from Cincinatti.  Norton is played by Barry Pepper, in his best performance of his entire career.  Sherriff Belmont (Dwight Yoakam) is put on the case, but never works on it.  Yoakam gives another specialty performance as the slimy sherriff, a performance that he paralelled in Billy Bob Thornton's Sling Blade.  It soon comes to the attention of Pete Perkins that Norton is responsible for Melquiades' death, and Pete kidnaps Mike and forces him on a near impossible journey to Mexico to give Estrada a proper burial.  On the way, nothing seems to go right for Pete.  Estrada's body takes damage along the way (other than the natural decay), falling off of a cliff, being set on fire, and being eaten by ants.  The journey takes a psychological toll on Pete, an takes a strong physical toll on Mike.  After a horse tumbles on Pete, Mike takes a chance of escape, only to be hopelessly followed by Pete.  Mike is bitten by a rattlesnake, and in a turn of irony (the film is filled with strong irony), he is cured by a Mexican woman he assaulted at the Mexico-Texas border.  Pete and Mike begin a journey to find Jimenez, the town where Estrada claimed he was from, and they begin to wonder if it really exists.  The film is filled with death, darkness, and depression, with only a brief light towards the end of the film.  The film explores all kinds of aspects of human nature, psyche, etc., and through it all, the actors give top-notch performances.  Jones' directing and Guillermo Arriaga's wonderful script make The Three Burials of Melquiades Estrada one of the year's best films, and one of the best modern westerns ever made.
summary: Realism and Westerns Do Go Well Together

reviewText: Tommy Lee Jones' sophomore effort (following his directorial debut THE GOOD OLD BOYS) is a wonderful movie of both beauty and complexity. Here we have a movie that works on so many different levels to deliver one of the finest american films in many a year.Set on the border between Texas and Mexico, which is a hotspot for illegal crossings into the US, the movie unfolds as a simple tale of friendship. Ranch foreman Pete Perkins (played by Jones, on fine form) learning of the death of his mexican friend Melquiades Estrada (Julio Cesar Cedillo). Told with a non linear narrative - with the action moving back and forth, and scenes playing out in many a different order, the viewer is drawn into an absorbing film that follows a man's pain of losing his friend and what he will do to honor that friendship. Flipping the imigration angle on its head, Pete takes his dead friend back across the border to Mexico (instead of the other way round) where he can be at peace with his wife and family. However, accompanying Pete on his journey is Melquiades' murderer - Mike (played to perfection by Barry Pepper), a lost texas border patrolman, stuck in a loveless marriage and prone to fits of violent behaviour towards the illegally crossing mexicans - he must share the journey with Pete and seek redemption for his sins.The film is as simple as that. A two hour trek across the border with Jones and Pepper, first at odds - then, at ease with each other. Its this simplicity and magnificent story telling that sets this film apart from any other. Beautifully shot, acted and written - this is a film of mood and metaphor. Relationships end and enemies become friends, people become stronger while others weaken and sometimes, police chiefs simply give up and go on vacation to Seaworld. Its that kind of movie.The cast are excellent and Guillermo Arriags' screenplay is both sorrowful and life affirming. Jones as a director is equal to his talents as an actor - he really is that good. Taking time when it needs to and not letting the scenery overtake the story - this is a director at the top of his game and one can only look forward to what he has coming next.Optimum's DVD is impressive. A superb transfer with all the usual assortment of extras - commentary and making of features. The 'making of' follows the movie through production and onto Cannes. All in all, a film of warmth and honesty, desperation and honour and well worth seeking out. Recommended.

reviewText: Tommy Lee Jones directs and stars in "The Three Burials of Melquiades Estrada", an off-beat darkly comic Western that plays out among a small group of ironically interconnected characters from a Texas border town. The body of Mexican ranch hand Melquiades Estrada (Julio Cesar Cedillo) is found dumped in the Texas desert, shot to death by parties unknown. Local cowboy Pete Perkins (Tommy Lee Jones) wants to know who killed his friend Melquiades, but Sheriff Frank Belmont (Dwight Yoakam) is reluctant to investigate the death of a wetback who was likely shot by Border Patrol. Pete's persistence leads him to the guilty party, however: a brutal Border Patrol cop named Mike Norton (Barry Pepper) whose disaffected wife (January Jones) is friendly with Pete's -and Frank's- sometimes lover Rachel (Melissa Leo). Pete decides to conscript Mike, at gunpoint, into a journey to return Melquiades' body to his home village in Mexico for burial."The Three Burials of Melquiades Estrada" looks promising for about an hour, as it flits back and forth in time, alternating between Pete's relationship with Melquiades, the circumstances of Mel's death, and the present quest to identify his killer. And the relationships between this sextet of characters emerge. Once the quest to bury Melquiades gets underway, however, the film's structure settles down to a continuous narrative that feels long and slow. And the characters' behavior becomes self-consciously quirky. The quixotic quest disconnects itself from the realism that preceded it, and I felt that the characters lost their emotional impact at that point. Not to mention that Mike, beaten up, worn out, and unable to change his clothes, somehow still manages to shave. The attempts to preserve Melquiades' body are grotesquely comic, but actually not as funny as corpse humor should be. There is some nice character writing in the first half of this film, and Tommy Lee Jones and Barry Pepper are always interesting actors. But "The Three Burials of Melquiades Estrada" derails partway through. In English and Spanish with English subtitles.The DVD (Sony Pictures 2006): Widescreen and full screen versions are included on the same disc. There is an audio commentary by Tommy Lee Jones, Dwight Yoakam, and January Jones. It's a sporadic, casual commentary in which the actors and director talk about anything that the scenes bring to mind. It doesn't have much depth, but most scenes do have some commentary.

reviewText: It's hard not to see this movie carrying some uncredited transpositions of Cormac McCarthy--a journey from Texas into Mexico by horseback in a challenge of a man's honor and friendship to another man, and with a not-so-subtle aura of violence along the way.Still, there's a lot to admire about this film.  The beginning gets a little flighty, switching too quickly among time periods in the storyline to introduce situations and characters, but once things finally do get moving, Tommy Lee Jones expertly chugs the film along as Peter Perkins, a wizened old cowboy who prefers staring off at the sun than making speeches, but delivers the weight of his hurt and anger every step of the way.  A good friend of his, the character named in the title of the movie, is gunned down by a too-eager border patrolman, and Peter not only wants revenge but to honor his friend's request to be buried in his homeland.The journey itself presents an intriguing question: just what is home?  The answer, of course, is worth watching the movie for.  The movie sometimes gets a little too caught up in trying to establish its grittiness, with quick-cut scenes of directionless dialogue.  Pardon the analogy, but it's hard not to make _Sling Blade_ references with Dwight Yoakam on the cast list--rather than hold the camera on scenes the way _Sling Blade_ does, to make us go along with the characters a little longer and get a fuller sense of each of them, _The Three Burials of Melquiades Estrada_ keeps moving away from the non-central characters and decides instead to let us only get full pictures of Perkins and the border guard, whom Perkins kidnaps to assist with the burial before revenge is taken.  Many of the other characters, like Perkins' love interest, a former prostitute who has merely moved away from making johns pay for her services, are intriguing, but in the end haven't been given full opportunity to reveal themselves the way Perkins and his captive are.This movie is a joy to watch if you're in the mood for a brooding cowboy only out to do the right thing, though there was clearly a larger ensemble here that could have made the movie sparkle.

reviewText: ****1/2Tommy Lee Jones` "The Three Burials of Melquiades Estrada" is a rare and extraordinarily interesting modern western centering around illegal immigration at the Texas/Mexico border.  The complicated plot begins with the discovery of a corpse half-buried in the Texas desert.  The shooting victim is one Melquiades Estrada, a young illegal immigrant with a wife and family back in Mexico.  His buddy, Pete Perkins (played by Jones himself), a gringo with a natural affinity for Mexican immigrants, discovers that the killer is a violent, hotheaded young border patrol agent named Mike Norton (Barry Pepper), who, it turns out, shot Estrada more out of fear and confusion than any sense of malice.  Realizing that the authorities have no intention of bringing Estrada's killer to justice, Pete takes matters into his own hands by kidnapping Norton and dragging him to Mexico on horseback so that together they can fulfill Estrada's expressed wish to be buried there in his native soil.Guillermo Arriaga has written a screenplay that is gritty, subtle and not at all interested in following a pre-arranged formula.  He allows the story to go off in unexpected directions and we are more than happy to follow right along with it.  So seamless is Arriaga in moving back and forth in time that it takes a full half hour before we realize that much of what we have been watching has actually been in the form of flashbacks.  Yet, rather than making us confused, this approach only piques our interest further and makes us want to see how it will all turn out.  Arriaga has also created characters with subtle shadings.  For instance, even though Perkins is acting out of righteous anger in defense of the friend he loved, some of his actions reveal an underlying element of sadism in his personality.  In much the same way, Norton is not portrayed as a one-dimensional villain, but rather as a deeply troubled man with the potential for redemption if someone could just find some way to tap the goodness that is lurking at his core.  Even though most of the scenes center around these two men, the film is filled with a whole host of memorable, finely drawn secondary characters who contribute both to the plot and to the desert community milieu of the film.As a director, Jones, working with cinematographer Chris Menges, makes the setting an integral part of the drama, showing how both the beauty and the harshness of the environment ultimately affect human behavior.  And Jones has elicited riveting performances not just from himself and Pepper, but from Dwight Yoakum, Melissa Leo and January Jones in various supporting roles.It's true that the film comes equipped with an obvious political slant; Jones and Arriaga portray the Mexicans in a far more sympathetic light than they do the border patrol officers or the American law enforcement officials.  It would be a shame, however, for a viewer to let that one aspect deprive him of reveling in the fine filmmaking and first-rate storytelling that is at the heart of "The Three Burials of Melquiades Estrada."

reviewText: Tommy Lee Jones' plays Pete Perkins in this film, a character who goes on an epic journey, a pilgrimage to bury his friend's body in the Mexican hometown where the friend asked to be returned. Jones looks the part for this type of raw, adult western. He has that dark, craggy, intensity that balances dangerously between lone star craziness and commitment to a cause.However visually right this movie is - I found it to be emotionally wrong. Viewers are not given enough background to make Perkins' attachment to migrant worker Estrada comprehensible or meaningful.  We are shown a couple of sparse flashback scenes of the men meeting, with a few words exchanged. Then we see the men briefly wrangling cattle together, with a few words exchanged. Then we see Estrada showing Perkins a picture of his wife and children, a family presumably left back in Mexico five years previous. Perkins seems to assent to Estrada's wish that if anything should happen to him while he is here on the alien soil of the United Stated, Perkins will see that Estrada's body is returned to his native land. Then Perkins supplies an extra woman for Estrada's pleasure, and the two couples romp, after Estrada gets in the spirit of the thing.But none of this is enough to explain why Perkins would go to such lengths to keep his promise to return Estrada's body. We begin to feel that the obligation he feels to the deceased "wetback" is just an excuse - an excuse for both masochism and for sadism. And sadistic rigors are heaped aplenty on the border guard who reportedly shot Estrada. This guard gets brutally dragged along on Perkins' pilgrimage in forced atonement.So apart from a sympathetic blind man who is encountered and abandoned along the way, there are no male characters here for the viewer to care about. And the women, as is so often the case in modern movies, are just there as bodies for the men to have sex with. They don't have any real lives of their own. They stand and wait and allow themselves to be groped, or make themselves available for booty calls. Other than that, their character development is limited to the occasional forlorn and vaguely longing looks they cast into the Texas vastness. Perhaps they are realizing that none of the men in their lives would make any arduous journey to grant them a burial wish. They will remain less than incidental to the harshly indifferent male principle that dominates the landscape.In summary, this movie is like a skull in a Georgia O'Keefe desert painting. It is visually arresting, but every bit of living organic matter that may have once adhered to its characters has long since been blown away on the desert wind. All that's left are the remains - of Estrada, and of them all.

reviewText: Tommy Lee Jones may have won his Oscar for playing the over-the-top Sam Gerard, but he gives the performance of his career as Pete in "The Three Burials of Melquiades Estrada."  He also demonstrates that he has the gifts of patience and restraint by the camera of Clint Eastwood - another assured actor-turned-director."Three Burials" has at its core a great story, filled with emotion and ambiguity.  Set in a tiny, thankless border town in Texas, "Three Burials" has a well-rounded cast of characters each seeking to find their place in a sun-blasted, dirty world.  Jones is the ranch-hand Pete, and he quickly befriends Estrada (Julio Cedillo), the handsome Mexican immigrant who claims to have left his beloved family back in a little slice of heaven in Mexico in order to find work.  Barry Pepper plays Mike Norton, an amped-up border patrolman married to the beautiful, bored Lou Ann (January Jones).  Country fans will recognize Dwight Yoakam as the loathsome Sheriff Belmont, and Melissa Leo ("Homicide") plays Rachel, the easy, seasoned waitress.  None of these characters have their defining characteristics stamped on their forehead in their first scene, and there is remarkable evolution even in the supporting characters.In a tragic misunderstanding, Norton kills Estrada (not a spoiler - the title kinda gives it away).  Pete takes the death hard, and tracks Norton down over the resistance of Belmont and the border patrol.  Soon, he's kidnapped Norton and forced him to dig up Estrada in order to re-inter him in his beloved home, Jimenez, with his family, per Estrada's request.Along the way, Jones takes the viewer through varying degrees of despair and triumph, redemption and collapse.  Characters find new strengths and confront their failings, all in a world realistically filmed and yet moving in its dusty grime (in the border town) or its beauty (in Mexico).  An understated soundtrack and an enigmatic ending complete this existential picture.A "little film," "Three Burials" creeps up on you.  I had initially planned on giving it four stars as an enjoyable film.  But it's been a week since I've seen it, and I've thought about it every day.  That's a rare film indeed.  Kudos to Jones and team for fine work.
summary: Jones' restraint behind and in front of the camera elevates "Burials"
